facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 106 of 1965 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 106 of 1965. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated November 13, 1962 of Punjab High Court Circuit Bench at Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order, dated November 13, 1962 of the Punjab High Court  Circuit Bench  at Delhi in Income-tax Reference Case No. 3 of 1959.

facts.text: Income-tax Reference Case No. 3 of 1959 in Punjab High Court.

anchor.surface_text: the Punjab High Court  Circuit Bench  at Delhi in Income-tax Reference Case No. 3 of 1959. V. Viswanatha Sastri, Gopal Singh and R. N. Sachthey, for the appellant.

facts.text: Reference made under section 66 of the Income Tax Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: the judgment of the High Court of Punjab at Chandigarh in a reference made to it under s. 66  1  of the Income Tax Act, 1922, hereinafter referred to as the Act.

facts.text: Assessment year 1947-48, accounting period calendar year ending 31st December 1946.

anchor.surface_text: The statement of case relates to the assessment year 1947-48, the accounting period being the calendar year ending 31st December, 1946.

facts.text: Assessee is a public limited company dealing in manufacture and sale of stationery goods.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee is a public limited companypany dealing in the manufacture and sale of stationery goods. Before the partition of the Country the companypanys registered office as well as the head office was at Lahore.

facts.text: Before partition, company's registered office and head office at Lahore.

anchor.surface_text: Before the partition of the Country the companypanys registered office as well as the head office was at Lahore. The assessment for the year 1947-48 was companypleted by the Pakistan Income-tax Officer on the 28th January, 1948 companypletely ignoring the agreement of the Avoidance of Double Taxation of Income between the Pakistan and the Indian Governments.

facts.text: Pakistan Income-tax Officer completed assessment for 1947-48 on 28th January 1948.

anchor.surface_text: The assessment for the year 1947-48 was companypleted by the Pakistan Income-tax Officer on the 28th January, 1948 companypletely ignoring the agreement of the Avoidance of Double Taxation of Income between the Pakistan and the Indian Governments.

facts.text: Pakistan assessment ignored agreement of Avoidance of Double Taxation between Pakistan and India.

anchor.surface_text: 1948 companypletely ignoring the agreement of the Avoidance of Double Taxation of Income between the Pakistan and the Indian Governments. The assessment for the year 1947-48 was also made by the Income-tax Officer 3rd Additional Business Circle, New Delhi on a figure of Rs. 38,916.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer 3rd Additional Business Circle, New Delhi made assessment for 1947-48 on Rs. 38,916.

anchor.surface_text: The assessment for the year 1947-48 was also made by the Income-tax Officer 3rd Additional Business Circle, New Delhi on a figure of Rs. 38,916. It is companymon ground that the assessee had paid advance tax under Section 18-A of the Indian Income Tax Act to the tune of Rs. 36,783/6/- between June. 1946 and March, 1947.

facts.text: Assessee paid advance tax Rs. 36,783/6/- under Section 18-A Indian Income Tax Act between June 1946 and March 1947 to Income-tax Officer, Lahore.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that the assessee had paid advance tax under Section 18-A of the Indian Income Tax Act to the tune of Rs. 36,783/6/- between June. 1946 and March, 1947. This tax was paid under the Indian Income-tax Act to the Income- tax Officer, Lahore.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer III Additional Business Circle New Delhi order dated March 1952 determined assessee's total income at Rs. 38,916 and directed demand notice and chalan.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer 111, Additional Business Circle, New Delhi, by his order, dated March. 1952, determined the total income of the respondent, M s. Bharat Carbon Ribon Manufac- turing Co., hereinafter to as the assessee at Rs. 38,916 and directed that demand numberice and chalan be issued.

facts.text: Assessee is M/s. Bharat Carbon Ribbon Manufacturing Co.

anchor.surface_text: determined the total income of the respondent, M s. Bharat Carbon Ribon Manufac- turing Co., hereinafter to as the assessee at Rs. 38,916 and directed that demand numberice and chalan be issued. Before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner one of the points taken up by the assessee was that credit should be given to him of the-advance tax paid by him in Lahore,

facts.text: Assessee claimed before Appellate Assistant Commissioner credit for advance tax paid in Lahore under s.18A.

anchor.surface_text: Before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner one of the points taken up by the assessee was that credit should be given to him of the-advance tax paid by him in Lahore, under s. 18A  11  which reads as follows Any sum other than a penalty or interest paid by or recovered from an assessee in pursuance of the provisions of this section shall be treated as a payment of tax in respect of the income of the period which would be the previous year for an assessment for the financial year next following the year in which it was payable, and credit therefore shall be given to the assessee in the regular assessment.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner disallowed the claim for credit of advance tax.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner disallowed the claim. He observed I, however, find that the amount under Section 18-A was paid by the assessee to Income-tax Officer, Lahore. The same Income- tax Officer made an assessment for this very year on 28th January, 1948 on a total income of Rs. 1,22,014 for Income tax and Rs. 52,780 for capital gains.

facts.text: Pakistan ITO assessed on 28 January 1948 total income Rs. 1,22,014 for income tax and Rs. 52,780 for capital gains, total tax Rs. 76,472/6/-.

anchor.surface_text: The same Income- tax Officer made an assessment for this very year on 28th January, 1948 on a total income of Rs. 1,22,014 for Income tax and Rs. 52,780 for capital gains. He worked out the total tax payable by the assessee at Rs. 76,472/6.

facts.text: Pakistan authorities adjusted advance tax of Rs. 47,513 against Pakistan demand, still Rs. 20,000 due from assessee.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of this assessment, even after setting off the tax paid under Section 18-A of Rs. 47,513 an amount of Rs. 20,000 was still due from this assessee. The amount under Section 18-A, has, therefore, been adjusted by the Pakistan authorities towards the. payment of tax and the assessee cannot take credit for this amount again.

facts.text: Assessee appealed to Appellate Tribunal, which allowed the claim for credit.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee filed an appeal before the Appellate Tribunal. The Tribunal allowed the claim on the ground that the language of s. 18A  11  was mandatory, and it was the duty of the Income. tax authorities to give credit for the amount paid by the assesses as advance tax in the regular assessment made under the Indian Income Tax Act.

facts.text: At instance of Commissioner of Income Tax, reference made to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the Commissioner of Income Tax a refer- ence was made to the High Court. The High Court held that if the direction companytained in s. 18A 11  had to be obeyed, credit had necessarily to be given to the assessee at the time of regular assessment.

facts.text: High Court answered both questions in the affirmative in favour of assessee.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the High Court answered both the questions in the affirmative. Mr. A. V. Viswanatha Sastri, the learned companynsel for the appellant, companytends before us that by virtue of s. 18 3  of the Indian Independence Act,

facts.text: Supreme Court holds assessee not entitled to adjustment of advance tax paid in Lahore against Indian demand for 1947-48.

anchor.surface_text: In the result we hold that the answer to the questions should be in the negative and against the assessee.

facts.text: Pakistan authorities had adjusted the advance tax against their assessment.

anchor.surface_text: The amount under Section 18-A, has, therefore, been adjusted by the Pakistan authorities towards the. payment of tax and the assessee cannot take credit for this amount again. Under these circumstances, it must be held that there was numberbalance of tax paid under Section 18-A left to be adjusted by the Income-tax Officer for the Indian assessment.

anchor.surface_text: Section 18 3  of the Indian Independence Act reads as follows Save as otherwise expressly provided in this Act, the law of British India and of the several parts thereof existing immediately before the appointed day shall, so far as applicable and with the necessary adaptations, continue as the law of each of the new Dominions and the several parts thereof until other provision is made by laws of the Legislature of the Dominion in question or by any other Legislature or other authority having power in that behalf.

concepts.interpretation: Resulted in simultaneous application of Income Tax Act in both Dominions, allowing dual adjustment of advance tax without increasing the amount paid.

issues.text: Whether the assessee was entitled to have an adjustment of the advance tax paid by it under Section 18-A of the Indian Income-tax Act in Lahore for the assessment year 1947-48 against the demand of tax raised by the Income-tax Officer 3rd Additional Business Circle, New Delhi for the assessment year 1947-48?

issues.text: Whether by virtue of s. 18(3) of the Indian Independence Act, the advance tax paid by the assessee prior to partition was liable to be adjusted against assessments in both Pakistan and India, precluding further credit in the Indian assessment after adjustment in Pakistan?

arguments.claim: By virtue of s.18(3) Indian Independence Act, advance tax adjustable against both Pakistan and India assessments; Pakistan adjusted so nothing left for India

anchor.surface_text: Mr. A. V. Viswanatha Sastri, the learned counsel for the appellant, contends before us that by virtue of s. 18 3  of the Indian Independence Act, the Income Tax Act as it existed before the coming into force of the Indian Independence Act, applied both to the Dominion of Pakistan and the Dominion of India, and the result of this simultaneous application to both the Dominions was that the advance tax paid by the assessee was liable to be adjusted against the assessments made both in Pakistan and in India,

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed that s.18(3) changed incidents of advance tax to allow adjustment against two assessments but same amount

arguments.claim: Government of India obligated under s.9 Indian Independence Rights Order to refund advance tax or give credit in India; relies on Dwarka Dass case and High Court reasoning

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel for the respondent relies on the reasoning of the High Court and on Dwarka Dass v. Income-tax Officer, Kanpur 1  and says that it was the obligation of the Government of India under s. 9 of the Indian Independence  Rights, Property and Liabilities  Order, 1947, either to refund the money paid as advance tax or to give credit in the assessment in India.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: y some assessment proceedings were pending. It was also companymon ground that excess payments had been made by the petitioner in that case under s. 1

arguments.court_reasoning: Not necessary to consider s.9 as case decided on s.18(3) IIA; Dwarka Dass distinguished

arguments.claim: s.18(3) Indian Independence Act changed incidents of advance tax from single to dual adjustment against India and Pakistan assessments but amount remains same so no double credit after Pakistan adjustment

anchor.surface_text: Section 18 3  of the Indian Independence Act reads as follows Save as otherwise expressly provided in this Act, the law of British India and of the several parts thereof existing immediately before the appointed day shall, so far as applicable and with the necessary adaptations, continue as the law of each of the new Dominions and the several parts thereof until other provision is made by laws of the Legislature of the Dominion in question or by any other Legislature or other authority having power in that behalf.

arguments.claim: Dwarka Dass case distinguishable as no regular Pakistan assessment there unlike here where Pakistan made regular assessment and adjusted tax

anchor.surface_text: Dwarka Dasss case 1  relied on by the learned counsel for the assessee is distinguishable because that case proceeded on the assumption that no regular assessments had been made in Pakistan for the relevant years and only some assessment proceedings were pending. It was also common ground that excess payments had been made by the petitioner in that case under s. 18A of the Indian Income Tax Act in Lahore

arguments.claim: No need to consider s.9 Indian Independence Rights Order as case decided on s.18(3) IIA

anchor.surface_text: In this view it is not necessary to consider the interpretation of s. 9 of the Indian Independence  Rights, Property and Liabilities  Order, 1947. By virtue of the simultaneous application of the Indian Income Tax Act in both the Dominions, there was  1  29 I.T.R. 60. a statutory modification of the incidents of the advance tax paid by the assessee.

holdings.text: the answer to the questions should be in the negative and against the assessee

anchor.surface_text: In the result we hold that the answer to the questions should be in the negative and against the assessee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Advance tax under s.18A(11) already adjusted by Pakistan against its assessment; no balance available for credit in Indian assessment due to effect of s.18(3) Indian Independence Act continuing the Act in both dominions

holdings.text: the effect of s. 18 3 of the Indian Independence Act was to change the incidents of the advance tax paid [...] the advance tax was liable to be adjusted against two regular assessments, one by India and one by Pakistan

anchor.surface_text: in our opinion the effect of s. 18  3  of the Indian Independence Act was to change the incidents of the advance tax paid. Previously the advance tax was to be adjusted towards a single regular assessment to be made by British India. After the Indian Independence Act the advance tax was liable to be adjusted against two regular assessments, one by India and one by Pakistan.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.18(3) continued pre-partition Income Tax Act in both new dominions with adaptations, modifying advance tax from single to dual adjustment possibility without increasing the paid amount

holdings.text: if the assessee has been given credit for the advance tax by the Pakistan Government, he cannot claim that credit should be given to him by the Indian Income Tax authorities

anchor.surface_text: It follows that if the assessee has been given credit for the advance tax by the Pakistan Government, he cannot claim that credit should be given to him by the Indian Income Tax authorities.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Same advance tax amount cannot be credited twice following simultaneous application of Income Tax Act in India and Pakistan under s.18(3) IIA; Pakistan adjustment exhausts the credit

holdings.text: The effect of the Indian Independence Act was not to double the advance money the assessee had paid. The amount of money he paid as advance tax remained the same

anchor.surface_text: The effect of the Indian Independence Act was number to double the advance money the assessee had paid. The amount of money he paid as advance tax remained the same. Having been given credit by the Pakistan Government he companyld number claim that there was any amount left on which s. 18  A 11 companyld operate.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.18(3) IIA adaptations do not multiply the advance tax paid; single payment adjustable against dual assessments but fully utilized by one precludes the other

holdings.text: Dwarka Dasss case relied on by the learned counsel for the assessee is distinguishable because that case proceeded on the assumption that no regular assessments had been made in Pakistan

anchor.surface_text: Dwarka Dasss case 1  relied on by the learned companynsel for the assessee is distinguishable because that case proceeded on the assumption that numberregular assessments had been made in Pakistan for the relevant years and only some assessment proceedings were pending. It was also companymon ground that excess payments had been made by the petitioner in that case under s. 18A of the Indian Income Tax Act in Lahore

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unlike Dwarka Dass where no Pakistan regular assessments made and excess payments involved, here Pakistan completed regular assessment and adjusted advance tax

holdings.text: it is not necessary to consider the interpretation of s. 9 of the Indian Independence Rights, Property and Liabilities Order, 1947

anchor.surface_text: In this view it is number necessary to companysider the interpretation of s. 9 of the Indian Independence  Rights, Property and Liabilities  Order, 1947. By virtue of the simultaneous application of the Indian Income Tax Act in both the Dominions, there was  1  29 I.T.R. 60. a statutory modification of the incidents of the advance tax paid by the assessee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Issue avoided as case resolved on interpretation of s.18(3) Indian Independence Act

holdings.text: By virtue of the simultaneous application of the Indian Income Tax Act in both the Dominions, there was a statutory modification of the incidents of the advance tax paid by the assessee

anchor.surface_text: By virtue of the simultaneous application of the Indian Income Tax Act in both the Dominions, there was  1  29 I.T.R. 60. a statutory modification of the incidents of the advance tax paid by the assessee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Continuation under s.18(3) IIA resulted in statutory change to pre-partition advance tax incidents due to dual dominion application

precedents.cited_proposition: obligation of the Government of India under s. 9 of the Indian Independence Rights, Property and Liabilities Order, 1947, either to refund the money paid as advance tax or to give credit in the assessment in India

anchor.surface_text: Dwarka Dasss case 1  relied on by the learned companynsel for the assessee is distinguishable because that case proceeded on the assumption that numberregular assessments had been made in Pakistan for the relevant years and only some assessment proceedings were pending. It was also companymon ground that excess payments had been made by the petitioner in that case under s. 18A of the Indian Income Tax Act in Lahore in respect of the years 1946-47 and 1947- 48, and it was only these excess payments that the Allahabad High Court had directed should be set off against the assessments of the subsequent years.

anchor.surface_text: in our opinion the effect of s. 18  3  of the Indian Independence Act was to change the incidents of the advance tax paid. Previously the advance tax was to be adjusted towards a single regular assessment to be made by British India. After the Indian Independence Act the advance tax was liable to be adjusted against two regular assessments, one by India and one by Pakistan.
In the result we hold that the answer to the questions should be in the negative and against the assessee.
